title: What are some of the most common challenges professional musicians face? - Quora

response.answer_text: Finding work/getting “discovered”, depending on your goalImmense competitionNo regular paycheckThe constant threat of technology replacing youVery few musicians have predictable hours and many have extremely arduous schedulesThe business can be extremely hard on your self-worth and most musicians tend to be on the more emotional side, so that makes it toughThe business can be cut-throat (which is a factor of “immense competition”.If you are an instrumentalist that looks for session work or an orchestral position, you often have to wait for an established player to die because the industry finds its favorite, experienced session players and uses them whenever possible (and there are a lot of them); the orchestras usually keep their players as long as their performance is on par with the standards. (Again, intense competition).Most people who graduate intending to teach music in schools find that the programs are being de-funded and, again, many prospects for few jobs.I am sure there are other factors, but these are the ones that come to mind immediately.

Hi, this question really makes me think…what, why are you asking me? I'm no professional musician and have a past career in admin. banking with the future looking to move into a peer support worker! But I enjoy the challenge of this one… What are some of the most common challenges professional musicians face? Without going into depth I thought I would provide you with seven challenges that professional musicians face: Challenge #1: Wearing too many hats Challenge #2: Finding reliable band members Challenge #3: Maintaining energy Challenge #4: Building support Challenge #5: Not getting discouraged Challenge #6: The competition Challenge #7: Staying motivated These challenges are brief and bring home the point. To me I found the message is to keep it simple, have people who will be there and finding energy. Learn who are your support through the process. Try not to let things get you down. A really important issue is being aware of your competition. When you start out, there will be a fire in your belly that will need to be maintained. If you love what you do and enjoy having fun it won't seem like a job or work. Your days will pass very quickly and you will have some great memories. Also, if you make a mistake, stop, think about it, learn from it and try not to make the same mistake again! So have fun in making music for us to listen to! xx wendy

Nikolaos, to me the most difficult challenge is making a living doing what you have chosen as your life’s profession. The music industry is competitive and ever changing. You have to showcase yourself and be recognized as your peers are doing the same. This can be even more of a challenge if you happen to be a member of the music genre currently in vogue. Think how many more artists of that genre are trying to do so. Another difficulty is finding and keeping an audience. You might be lucky enough to be part of a genre like rock who still have fans long after the genre itself has waned. Or you could have been a disco era musician who had a short lived genre and has since struggled to remain relevant to fans. These are difficulties for sure, but think how hard any of this would be if you were not a star in your field. Everyone involved in this process has a financial incentive. Club owners, managers and music producers are looking for acts that will make them money. They have to see the ‘win’ in taking on you and your music. If they don’t see you as at least a ‘cash calf’ you won’t make much money. And by the way, the competition never ceases.

For me the challenges depend on what the musician is doing at the time. If he’s touring, it won’t matter if he’s playing cover songs or his own stuff. What matters is exhaustion. I know so many musicians are self conscious about their image so they won’t admit that exhaustion’s a big reason they get involved with drugs. As a singer you don’t want to drink alcohol, because it dilates the vessels in your vocal chord and your voice will suffer. So, as a “pick me up,” many of them turn to other stimulants. Whatever they choose is strictly a personal choice since everyone is different. If they’re recording original stuff, the biggest challenge is coming up with new stuff that’s as good as the first stuff. Usually a musician has no trouble having material already on hand, because they’ve been writing it for years and had plenty of struggle and adventures to inform the songs on the first recording. The second or third album might be tougher, because the biggest challenge you’ve faced since your first album and successful tour was missing luggage and bad food.

Richard Scherer provides excellent insight into the “professional” challenges faced by pro musicians. I’ll address another facet, the work-life balance, at least for a jazz musician. Those that are performing (or doing studio work) for 100% of their income have it tougher to have a home/personal life, they’re constantly on the road touring. A few others seem to be able to do teaching as well as performing, and I’m referring to two fellow musicians who combine teaching at college level with performing, the latter mostly done during the summer.

Lack of physical resources. Having the upfront money to kick start a tour, an abulm, gear purchases and merch. Sometimes this is as little as a few hundred dollars, but well paid work can be scarce.Needing to learn more than one industry to succeed. Being a professional musician necessitates that you understand and can run a small business, you also need to understand marketing and logistics.Being emotionally resilient and street smart. I think the modern music industry is often the worst fit for the types of people wanting to work in it. Most musicians are empathetic and caring and the music industry is by intention or fault designed to be cut throat and competitive. It’s also shark infested waters with so many opportunities offering you fame and a chance at big money but really just eating all the pennies from musicians pockets.I’ll add one more; being willing to work. What pays and what is artistic are often two different things.

It depends on the level. At the top, there is ever-increasing pressure to outdo your last tour, video, movie, or recording. Should you slip, you can be a has-been in a year. Some have made a comeback, some haven’t. Intense scrutiny of your personal life is a part of the package. As a musician at a lower intermediate level, the biggest problems I have encountered are logistical. Trying to find a parking place is a problem sometimes. Loading in can be a problem if there is a crowd when you get there. A big problem is trying to figure out how to set up a four or five piece band on a 3 foot by 3 foot stage. Sometimes you have to pay for parking, while the other employees do not. After all this, some club owners will try to screw you out of all or part of your pay.

I’m going to cite jazz trumpet great Lester Bowie, who would tell his students “the irst thing you must do is learn to feed yourself with your horn.” By that, he meant that they had to make money, and to do that they would have to be ready to play any job that paid. Wedding receptions, commercials, country-and-western, political conventions—if the job paid, you took it. Once you had gotten your income level, you then, he said, could focus on your art and pursue personal interests in your music. I realized when I was a music major in college that, in fact, I was not willing to follow Lester’s advice, so I went into teaching and let performing be my hobby. So there are other things you can do as a profession if you aren’t willing to “sell out”.

I have performed for years in upscale restaurants, lounges, country clubs and for special events. For me personally it is finding work. Today there are more musicians around than places that use live music. I used to find steady gigs but that almost doesn’t exist any longer. Most places today want somebody differenent every week and many places only use live music one night a week. Once there were local entertainment agencies that booked gigs but most of them are gone now. I work a day job and it’s hard for me to be constantly looking for work. It seems that the demand is no longer there. Times change.

Recognition when they are new, constant turnover of band mates when they are starting out. Making enough money to live on while getting started. Thinking they are good enough to be the star when they aren't. I have one friend who was married to a professional musician when he first started out, and some of the challenges the musician faced were his ego, alcohol, and cheating on my friend. They have been divorced for years, and he has been an amazing father to their children and from what she has seen has improved his behavior.

It’s similar to professional actors, I’d say: not starvingkeeping our chins up through incessant turn-downsfollowing our hearts no matter what … or dealing with the consequences of ‘compromising’if fame ‘hits’ … dealing with the self-worth issues that come with thatStill, in the end … it beats working at Starbucks! (I think …) Then … there’s those tuba and bass viol players … for them it’s just getting their instruments from Point A to Point B! And the poor pianists - playing whatever they walk into, usually poorly tuned!

Finding enough work. Since the dram laws finding servers responsible for DUIs, most bars and lounges don’t do enough business for live music. And since people record at home, a lot of recording jobs have vanished. Plus there’s fewer people interested in learning instruments because they think they can learn from the internet. I wish I had gotten into something honest and straight forward, like gun-running.

Being on the road away from family is likely the most significant challenge musicians face. I guess you have to strike a balance between your art, the recognition it receives and a happy home life. Making money. The vast majority of musicians have not hit the “Big Time” playing large venues for big money. Just surviving while trying to do what you love is enough of a challenge. There's a reason for the often used term, Starving Artist.

Here are some challenges I believe a musicians face here in Australia. Maintaining courage and motivation in a world that has no respect for musicians. Constantly facing the need to justify one’s existence is very tiring, as is having to explain why what you do is worth ‘X’ dollars. Maintaining a performance level (i.e. practicing), including sight reading, improvising, and technical facility. Constant travel and being away from family. (The previous answer is even more difficult being away all the time). Keeping healthy, and eating properly when you’re often not home. Looking after your hands when you have to carry heavy equipment.

The most common challenge is for them to be a true artist by developing their own creative talent instead of sacrificing their artistic integrity by playing cover songs. Playing great music that someone else created is relatively easy. Creating great original music is very difficult, so they’ll use any excuse to avoid that challenge. While millions of those mindless copycat clones pretend to be artists only fool themselves and their peers, the truth is they are just fakes making a literal mockery of the art of music.

the most common challenges would be the choice of either doing a gig for very little money or holding out to do gigs that pay what musicians deserve my music career is my second career now I make good money when I play at least two hundred bucks each time I do a show however I don't do it every night it's hard to book that many shows and be able to sing every night especially when you're in a cover band you supposed to be expected to sing 3 or 4 hours can't do that everyday for a living your voice to be gone within a few months but I love performing I love you making music I don't play bars and I don't play clubs I can only do private and public events that way there's not a bunch of drunk people heckling us and there's a people there they're wanting to see and they have requested us

Some have psychological issues…feelings of lack of self- worth. The thing is, life at the very top of the rung brings its own demands. It is highly competitive, there are up-and-coming young performers and people are always on the look out for fresh talent. I know a pianist who feels somewhat “displaced" and that's hard to deal with, especially when the engagements start to dry up or, in her case, you start to habituate a lower rung on the ladder.

The rigorous job of touring 6 to 8 months every time you record a new album. Going from town to town having to play the same set list every night & living out of your tour bus or hotel room every night. It gets a little cramped & boring but fans don’t know that part because they see them on or two nights & then they’re on to the next town. It’s a very grueling life & takes it toll on the entire entourage….

Getting paid. “here, come play in my bar, I’ll give you a drink or two, and you can pass a hat, but I can’t afford to pay you. It’ll be great exposure, though.” How about you cater my gig, you can put out your tip jar, I’ll dedicate a couple songs to you, but I can’t pay you anything. I guarantee , though, it’ll be great exposure for you club/restaurant.

Dj’s…. no offense to DJ’s but hitting play on a laptop doesn’t make you a musician. In the midwest in the 80’s,every bar wanted a live band. now every bar can hire a dj for half the money and he with the internet has every song in the world at his finger tips..bands work hard, practice and still can’t compete with “instant”..

Being listened to. It’s hard to become famous for your music and even harder to have a career that lasts longer than your first song. Then there’s the problem with your managers, funding for touring, musicians. Being told to make the same song as your first hit. Being a musician is complicated.

Inside of yourself you deal with self doubt and criticism, outside of yourself when trying to get gigs you deal with self doubt and criticism :-) You need to find love and trust inside and outside of yourself and have that be your strength. Just like life IMHO :!)

Reigning in their egos at the merest whiff of success and not having an exit strategy if things don’t ‘lift off’; it’s awful to be so crucified by ambition that the whole of a life and all of its potential width of experiences are continually put on hold in the tunnel visioned vain hope of success.
I would have to say getting exposure to large audiences and making fans were two of my biggest challenges as a professional musician. Luckily my band was able to get both but it took several years.
I think musicians are like any other business people that you may have to continue developing new things to attract others. Creativity is key.
Getting a fair deal from the publishers, record label and not getting ripped off by festival managers who often don't pay acts, dodgy
Eating regular. Paying your rent on time. Keeping the lights and heat on. Maintaining a relationship. Avoiding drug addiction and alcoholism. Little things like that.
Starvation and homelessness.
